articles.headline: Despair in Mariupol’s last stronghold: ‘They’re bombing us with everything’
articles.snippet: A huge Soviet-era steel mill is where the last Ukrainian defenders of Mariupol have taken refuge as Russia’s battle to take full control of the city appeared to be entering its final stages.
articles.abstract: A huge Soviet-era steel mill is where the last Ukrainian defenders of Mariupol have taken refuge as Russia’s battle to take full control of the city appeared to be entering its final stages.
articles.lead_paragraph: DNIPRO, Ukraine — Under incessant fire from the air and with Russian troops closing in, a group of Ukrainian soldiers holed up in the besieged city of Mariupol issued a message of despair on Tuesday evening, expressing hope that their own forces would come to their rescue and demanding that the world do something to stop the Kremlin’s vicious war.
articles.byline: By Michael Schwirtz, Cora Engelbrecht and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: The U.S. Races to Arm Ukraine With Heavier, More Advanced Weaponry
articles.snippet: Washington and its allies are scouring Central Europe and the world to get Ukraine the weapons it needs for the next phase of the war.
articles.abstract: Washington and its allies are scouring Central Europe and the world to get Ukraine the weapons it needs for the next phase of the war.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Elon Musk Races to Secure Financing for Twitter Bid
articles.snippet: The world’s richest man is trying to shore up debt financing, including potentially taking out a loan against his shares of Tesla, so he can buy Twitter for $43 billion.
articles.abstract: The world’s richest man is trying to shore up debt financing, including potentially taking out a loan against his shares of Tesla, so he can buy Twitter for $43 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk is racing to secure funding for his $43 billion bid to buy Twitter.

articles.headline: More Cautious, Russia Embarks on New Phase of Ukraine War
articles.snippet: Despite the Kremlin’s new methodical approach focusing on eastern Ukraine, the Russian military still faces some of the same problems that hampered it after the war began.
articles.abstract: Despite the Kremlin’s new methodical approach focusing on eastern Ukraine, the Russian military still faces some of the same problems that hampered it after the war began.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHARKIV, Ukraine — Russia plunged into a new chapter of the Ukraine war on Tuesday, intent on capturing the eastern part of the country and crushing Ukrainian defenses without the same blunders that badly damaged Russian forces in the conflict’s initial weeks.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Michael Schwirtz and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: With Joy and Fear, Americans Watch Sweeping Mask Rules Vanish
articles.snippet: Many travelers removed their masks after a judge struck down a federal mandate for public transit. Health experts voiced concern, but President Biden said it was now up to individuals.
articles.abstract: Many travelers removed their masks after a judge struck down a federal mandate for public transit. Health experts voiced concern, but President Biden said it was now up to individuals.
articles.lead_paragraph: It began in midair. Shortly after a federal judge struck down mask requirements on planes, pilots got on intercoms to share the news, and some passengers tore off their masks with whoops and glee.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: With Inflation, Workers Are Facing Return-to-Office Sticker Shock
articles.snippet: The cost of a daily routine — travel, coffee, food — is far pricier than it was when offices shut down two years ago.
articles.abstract: The cost of a daily routine — travel, coffee, food — is far pricier than it was when offices shut down two years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the security software company KnowBe4 weighed whether to require a return to the office, executives knew to anticipate a certain set of concerns from employees. Less flexibility. More time in transit.

articles.headline: Deep in Colombia, Rebels and Soldiers Fight for the Same Prize: Drugs
articles.snippet: The country signed a historic peace deal more than five years ago. But a power vacuum is fueling the rise of new armed groups competing to control the drug trade.
articles.abstract: The country signed a historic peace deal more than five years ago. But a power vacuum is fueling the rise of new armed groups competing to control the drug trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUTUMAYO, Colombia — In a rebel-held town deep in the jungle, Joel ran drills beside his comrades, line after line of them in camouflage and boots, rifles at their sides.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
